awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II: Novel Autonomous Electronic Methods to Prevent Biofouling
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project addresses the worldwide issue of how biofouling (unwanted attachment of biological species, e.g., barnacles, oysters, mussels) of ships is addressed. The current antifouling methods are harmful to the environment (toxic paints are employed and they can pollute waterways) and costly in terms of maintenance to mitigate biofouling and the increased fuel costs due to frictional drag during a vessel’s operation. This project seeks to develop an innovative, electronic approach to biofouling prevention by developing ultrasonic transducer arrays that are optimized for submerged operation in a marina. The near-term commercial opportunity is with both marina owners and nationwide marina operators. Over time and with further product development, commercial transport and large Navy vessels may also be addressed. This project seeks to enhance the scientific understanding of acoustic wave generation in water using piezoelectric transducers and sensor arrays along with the understanding of how these waves prevent the attachment of bio-species to ship hulls.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project seeks to address the challenges of commercial deployment of transducer and sensor arrays to prevent biofouling of ships docked in marinas. The program has four scientific objectives: 1) Improve transducer and power amplifier components and construction to maximize sound pressure levels in water; 2) Develop and construct complex coherent transducer arrays to project adequate sound pressure levels at distances greater than 10 feet to prevent biofouling agents from attaching to ships; 3) Integrate sensor arrays into an autonomous system that can adjust sound pressure levels based on feedback algorithms; and 4) Develop a proof-of-concept system to adopt an autonomous, electronically steerable transducer array system to the interior of boat hulls. This latter adaptation may open markets where large ships such as commercial transport and Naval vessels can be addressed.  The project will innovate in areas such as acoustic beam steering, electronic design of piezoelectric transducers, acoustic amplifier design, submersible marine electronics, and electro/mechanical design for submersible housings.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
The problem of Biofouling, the growth of unwanted species on submerged structures and boats, is a $120B problem in the USA alone and a migraine headache to Recreational Boaters, the Navy, Coast Guard, Cruise Lines, and Commercial shipping vessels. The long-standing solution to controlling biofouling is using Toxic Antifouling Paints on the hull and manually scraping fouling structures off the paint by divers. This causes paint to be released into the Sea Beds, creating more toxicity than the leaching of heavy metals into the water from the antifouling paint. This practice is a pervasive danger to the environment of the world's oceans. Transporting invasive species (non-native fouling organisms)  attached to boats has become a worldwide problem. 

The foremost objective of this NSF-funded project is to design and bring to market an external antifouling system that prevents biofouling on vessels without relying on toxic hull coatings. WaveArray has developed a system external to the ship that “paints” ultrasonic energy on the boat using completely electronic means (no moving parts). This ultrasonic energy creates an intense “moat” of microbubbles. This innovative solution employs an Electronic Steerable Coherent Array of Ultrasonic Emitters to prevent biofouling, eliminating the need for toxic coatings. This technology addresses the challenge of biofouling accumulation, which is a major problem for vessels of all types. Biofouling larvae born to attach to submerged structures can’t swim through the bubble moat. This results in the WaveArray system preventing biofouling.  In addition, a fouled ship can burn up to 60 % more fuel due to hull drag, causing large increases in CO2 emissions. 

To help understand how the system works, refer to Fig 1, which shows a boat drawing in a slip and the WaveArray system painting ultrasonic energy on the boat's hull. WaveArray has developed three systems. The first is the Slip Array system that surrounds a boat in a slip and protects the entire underwater ship's hull. Figure 2 shows a 62-foot yacht customer installation on Marco Island, FL. WaveArray's latest and most ambitious installation is on a 130 ft Yacht in Boca Ratan, Fl., see Figure 3. 

WaveArray has also developed systems designed to help Marinas with their biofouling problems. One is for a floating dock pillar, the Dock Array, a type of dock in which rollers on a cement Pillar allow the dock to float up and down with the tide. If a pillar gets fouled, the rollers can get stuck, causing the dock to break. Marinas have had costly repairs due to this problem. In Figure 4, you can see the fouling occurring without the WaveArray system and no fouling in the critical area of the pillar with the WaveArray system.

A Cable Array was designed to address a nasty problem Marinas encountered. As you can see in Figure 5, very heavy fouling occurs on the Cables that connect the floating dock to the marina's fixed infrastructure. These cables will eventually break due to the fouling weight, so WaveArray designed and deployed the Cable Array. That system uses the same principles as the Slip and Dock Array and keeps the Cables free of biofouling. 

Finally, the Port of Call system, installed inside the boat and capable of traveling with the vessel to ports anywhere in the world, is currently under development using WaveArray's patented technology. 

In summary, the NSF awards have been a springboard for the development of WaveArrays products that we feel will significantly reduce costs and operational problems related to biofouling for recreational boat owners, Navy and Coast Guard vessels, Cruise Line Companies, Commercial Shipping by Sea Industry, and Marina owners, while overcoming the long-standing damage to the environment of the world's water ecosystem.


 

 


Last Modified: 10/17/2024
Modified by: James V Dilorenzo
